urn:contentItem:5VMN-8FH1-JBHT-D4K3-00000-00U.S. Warns Germany Against Using Technology Of China's Huawei; Global Airlines Ground Boeing 737 Max Jets After Second Fatal Crash; Socialism VS. Capitalism; Tech Tackles Privacy Issues; Musk Pushes Back on SEC2019-03-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:46ZLexisNexisU.S. Warns Germany Against Using Technology Of China's Huawei; Global Airlines Ground Boeing 737 Max Jets After Second Fatal Crash; Socialism VS. Capitalism; Tech Tackles Privacy Issues; Musk Pushes Back on SECLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thank you so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, March 12. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast on the button. Markets this morning are lower. We are near -- well, we're off of the lows of the morning but certainly off of the highs as well.

Dow industrials down 65 points, Boeing is now another drag on the Dow this morning. S&P 500 just went negative a few minutes ago, down a quarter point but the NASDAQ up, this morning up 8-1/2, up nine points right now on NASDAQ, on top of big gains yesterday. Stocks staged a late-day rally yesterday driven by technology stocks. DowIndustrials were up 200 points, three- quarters of a percent, the S&P was up 1-1/2 percent.

But take a look at the NASDAQ, it was up 150 points due to the strength in tech, better than two percent on the session yesterday. Global markets this morning are mixed. Take a look at the European indices where the FT-100 is up 18 points, quarter of a percent but the CAC Quarante in Paris is down 15 and the DAX Index in Germany down 25. In Asia overnight, gains across-the-board the best performer was Japan, Nikkei Average up 1-3/4 percent.

Well, the groundings of Boeing 737 Max 8 jet are expanding across the world. Nearly half of all of the jets that have been delivered since May of '17 are now parked. The fallout coming up this morning for Boeing as the stock trades down another two percent as we speak. Carlos Ghosn replaced the Renault-Nissan alliance unveiling a new board structure as the automakers chart their path forward. As you know, Carlos Ghosn is now out of jail on bail.

Tesla CEO Elon Musk fires back at regulators this morning. What he said about his tweeting habits later this hour. Stock is down again 1-1/2 percent. And the internet us turning 30 years old. Google celebrates with its doodle today but the man behind the World Wide Web has a warning about the future.

All those stories coming up this Tuesday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network Dagen McDowell, the author of Love Your Enemies and the president of AEI, Arthur Brooks is in studio this morning and CFRA Investment Strategist, Lindsey bell. Great to see you this morning.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA RESEARCH: Good morning.

ARTHUR BROOKS, PRESIDENT, AMERICAN ENTERPRISE INSTITUTE: Good morning.

BELL: Lots to cover today, from Brexit, to the budget and Boeing.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We should point out because you mentioned that nearly half of the planes delivered since May of 2017 have been ground by other nations but the Federal Aviation Administration has held off grounding Boeing planes after the crash waiting to see what they find out about this particular crash, although the FAA is expected by the end of next month to mandate a software fix for the automated-flight control system that did play a role in the first crash in Indonesia.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Which is why -- what is it, southwest and American airlines have 737s, they haven't taken them out of the lineup, they're there as -- following the FAA's cues.

BELL: Well, and safety authorities here in the U.S. have been very careful on tying the Ethiopian Air accident just recently to the Lion Air accident that happened in October but you have China out there, their regulators saying that there could be a connection, it's really very uncertain, a lot of people here are saying it's too early to draw connection.

BROOKS: Their people -- the companies are very worried that the flying public is going to panic, and so that's why they're taking them off just in advance for that reason but there is no evidence at this point that there's a problem with the plane. I strongly suspect that it's -- it will be cleared quickly and Boeing is going to be fine.

MCDOWELL: Well, and China's reaction you have to look as Maria did yesterday at the backdrop of what's going on between the United States and China and some nations to suggest that China somehow knows more about a crash in Ethiopia than the U.S. safety regulators do and they were in the ground almost immediately in the country as part of the investigation of black boxes being -- have been recovered.

But there is that kind of rash move by some countries, potentially to make the United States look bad.

BARTIROMO: And Boeing sells a third of all of that plane 737 to China. Obviously, China --

BROOKS: It's an incredible safe aircraft. It has incredible safety record. There's no evidence that something horrible were going wrong worldwide.

BARTIROMO: Which is what Dennis Muhlenberg told us the end of last year, the CEO of Boeing. Meanwhile, President Trump outlines his plans to defense and border spending in his 2020 budget. Blake Burman is at the White House this morning with the very latest there. Blake, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you as well. This is third budget put forth by President Trump and his administration but the first time that they have put a budget forward in which Democrats control the appropriations process up on the Hill in the House of Representatives. The President wish list includes increasing defense spending by five percent, up to $750 billion.

While, also decreasing nondefense discretionary spending by that same amount, five percent. Pair that the request $8.6 billion for new funding for the border wall and it's why Democrats say this is going nowhere fast, dead on arrival. Senator Elizabeth Warren taking to Twitter last night, she wrote the following of the President's budget saying "A budget is more about -- is about more than numbers, a budget is about values and the budge the President released today is another big wet kiss to the super rich and giant corporations and it guts programs for everyone else."

Now, she is echoing complaints from Democrats about the spending levels for Medicare and Medicaid but the Trump administration insists those levels are not being rolled back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RUSSELL VOUGHT, ACTING WHITE HOUSE BUDGET DIRECTOR: What we are doing is putting forward reforms that lower drug prices that because Medicare pays a very large share of drug prices in this country, has the impact of finding savings. We're also finding ways, fraud, and abuse but Medicare spending will go up every year by healthy margins and no structural changes for Medicare beneficiaries.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: The budget that was put forth yesterday, Maria, would balance in 15th year. It also includes deficits of somewhere between a trillion dollars, and $1.1 trillion for fiscal years '19, '20, '21, and '22. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Big numbers there. Blake, thank you. Blake Burman at the White House. Joining us right now is the New Voice CEO, former Republican presidential candidate, Herman Cain. Herman, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

HERMAN CAIN, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, THE NEW VOICE: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Not every president gets his budget proposals materialized, right? What's your view on all of this?

CAIN: At least, it's a budget. I don't think the Democrats put forth a budget that was balanced in the eight years that Obama was president. Second, it doesn't matter what budget the President puts forth, the Democrats are going to punch holes in it. One of the most impressive parts of the budget to me is the fact that he says there is going to be a five percent across the board cut in nondiscretionary spening.

And it's going to come from looking for savings. This is what a leader does. The leader mandates a target and it's up to those that are running the various departments to go out and find those savings. I've had to do that as the CEO and that's exactly what the President is doing.

BROOKS: Hello, Mr. Cain, Arthur Brooks here from EEI. It's nice to see you again. I worry a lot when I see this, you know, when I see $1.1 trillion deficit in the best economy in the past 35 years which I saw great but we can't be running deficits like this when the thing is -- when we're an expansion, we're going to -- we're going to -- governments always do this, you know, we're going to -- we're balance this thing in the out-years.

We don't exactly know how but we're really going to do it and I know you've got to be skeptical about this too. So give some hard advice and some real criticism to your brother Republicans.

CAIN: The hard advice would be go find those savings, get serious about restraining spending. That would be the hard advice. The problem of it is that they never get serious about it. Republicans or Democrats.

BROOKS: Right.

CAIN: You can't just -- you can't just blame President Trump and his administration who has been there now a little over two years for this mess that we are in. Secondly, no one has mentioned that revenues to the treasury because of the tax cuts are up. So you've got those going up which is a good thing but he is now also trying to put the brakes on spending, and all the Democrats can do is criticize, criticize, criticize and say we're not going to approve any money fort wall,

I think the President has taken bold step and at least putting this directional budget on the table.

MCDOWELL: But he hasn't taken a step towards bold spending cuts because again what two-thirds of Federal spending, Herman, are on autopilot or because of entitlement programs. And there's no evidence -- again, President Trump ran on it, I'm not going to touch Social Security, I'm not going to touch Medicare, that's fine and dandy, I know he's got to run for reelection in 2020 again. But if you keep -- again, this never gets discussed and never gets talked about by anybody.

CAIN: You are right. Dagen. The non-- the discretionary portion hasn't been touched because it's to require central changes. The President has not addressed that yet. I agree with you. But if the President can't get a few measly billions of dollars for a wall, do you think that the Democrats and the liberals and the lunatics are going to let him get away within structural recommendations? No. Not yet. I don't know when he is going to do it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CAIN: But I do believe that before his first term is up he is going to get around to proposing some structural changes.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, they're going to be pushing back and they are pushing the Democratic National Committee looking into 2020 announcing that its chosen Milwaukee, Wisconsin to host the 2020 convention. Republicans were quick to point out that the socialist history is pretty alive and well in Milwaukee, the town has elected three socialist mayors in the past. The Wisconsin GOP tweeted this yesterday, with the 2020 Democrat presidential primary field currently stumbling over each other in a race for the radical left.

It makes sense that their party would choose to hold its convention and the only American city that has elected three socialist mayors. It feels like this 2020 election is going to be a very clear choice between socialism versus capitalism, Herman.

CAIN: I would absolutely agree with you. Let's not forget, Milwaukee is in Wisconsin and it's a big mea culpa on behalf of Hillary Clinton because she did not go there when she ran for president.

BARTIROMO: Right.

CAIN: That is the other factor I think is at play and trying to go and show some love to the State of Wisconsin. But a bigger point --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Herman, it can be summed up in two words.

CAIN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Cheese curds.

CAIN: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

BROOKS: The Democratic Party is doing an epic trolling --

(CROSSTALK)

BROOKS: -- by actually going to the state where she didn't -- she didn't campaign. They're just trolling their own candidate. This is the most amazing thing --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: And why would -- do they not realize that? Do they not get it? What about the issue of socialism versus capitalism? Are people clear on the differences? Do you think -- I mean, because, you know, you've got all of these ideas, the Green New Deal, you've got the Medicare for all, the tax on wealth, 70 percent tax rate. Do people understand what this means and what these Federal programs look like, socialist, federal government takeovers?

CAIN: Some people don't understand the difference between capitalism and socialism but the good news is most people know that socialism has never worked in a country, in the history of the world. So the Republicans and the conservatives and all the voices out there, the big challenge is to make sure that people understand.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CAIN: I am a firm believer that if people have the right information and the right understanding, they will make the right decision. That is no contest between capitalism and socialism. All you have to do is look at the success of the United States of America and make sure that the people understand that and they will not be swayed by these empty socialist promises coming from all the Democrat presidential wanna-bes.

BARTIROMO: Well, we'll see, we'll see. All right, Herman. Great to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

CAIN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: And we didn't even get to Nancy Pelosi saying she doesn't want to impeach the President, Herman. We'll save that for next time. Herman Cain.

CAIN: OK.

BARTIROMO: Coming up right after this, global backlash over Boeing this morning. More countries across the world moving to suspend the 737 Max 8 jet in the aftermath of the deadly crash in Ethiopia. We're breaking down the fallout. And then internet revolution. The World Wide Web turns 30 years old but its creator is issuing a warning sign. What he is saying. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back to MORNINGS WITH MARIA. I'm Cheryl Casone with some top headlines. We're following more countries are grounding Boeing's 737 Max 8 jet. Malaysia and Australia, the latest country to suspend the aircraft from their airports after the deadly crash in Ethiopia on Sunday. The countries follow similar moves in China, South Africa, Singapore, Indonesia, Brazil and Mexico.

But here in the United States the FAA says it has no plans to ground the aircraft for now but it has ordered Boeing to make urgent improvements to it. Boeing confirming it will deploy a software upgrade to the 737 Max 8. Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg defended the airplane's safety to Maria after the Lion Air crash.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MUILENBURG: The real bottom line here, the key is that the 737 Max is very safe and we're very confident in that. Safety is a core value for our industry and for our company. Always has been, it always will be.

BARTIROMO: But was there a change in terms of this model, the 737 that wasn't articulated to the pilots at the airlines that they did not know how to respond in the event of a change. That's what the charges are.

MUILENBURG: Yes. The 737 Max has some new capabilities that are embedded in it and that's included in the training process that we go through. You know, the airplane has gone through thousands and thousands of hours of testing and simulation, working with our pilots ensuring that they have all the information they need to safely operate the airplane. And in some cases, those new systems are designed to take advantage of the capabilities of the airplane.

We've already issued a couple of follow-up bulletins coming out of the ongoing investigation pointing pilots to existing flight procedures to handle with the kind of scenarios that we're talking about in this incident. So we're going to continue to do that. It's very important that we provide all of the information need to safely operate these airplanes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, Boeing stock down more than five percent yesterday. It is now lower again in the premarket today down 3-1/4 percent as you can see here. Well, Wells Fargo CEO Tim Sloan is going to testify before House Financial Services today, he's going to be grilled on the bank's fake account scandal. First time a bank CEO is going to appear before the committee that is now led by Democrats but Sloan's future is in question.

Regulators are seeking answers on whether he can repair the bank's image. Over the last year Wells Fargo stock down nearly 15 percent. Well, automakers Renault, Nissan and Mitsubishi have created a new board of directors that excludes former Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn. The new board will oversee the French-Japanese partnership meeting every month in Tokyo or Paris. Ghosn is still one of eight members of Nissan's board but his recent request to attend the Nissan board meeting was rejected by a judge.

Ghosn released last week from the Tokyo jail for $9 million bail after spending more than 100 days behind bars. He is accused of underreporting a salary at Nissan which he still denies. And then there is this, the internet 30 turns 30 today. Google celebrating with this doodle. You can see it if you go to Google. But the creator of the World Wide Web has a warning for all of us. In a blog post Tim Berners-Lee writes, the web has brought a lot of good but also dysfunction.

And he says it's time for everyone to work towards trying to change the web for the better. All right. We've got a lot more coming up. Investors eyeing U.S.-China trade as the top negotiators reportedly hold a call overnight. Plus, Elon Musk goes fighting back. The Tesla chief suggesting the SEC is infringing on his first amendment rights and holding him in contempt of court. We are breaking down the fallout when we come right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets were mixed today. A lot of questions about the U.S.-China trade story. Top officials from both countries holding a phone conversation last night, there still uncertainty since the meeting between President Trump and Xi Jinping has not been set which leaves investors anxious about the deal's future. Joining us right now is Market Compass LLC founder and CEO, Amelia Bourdeau. Good to see you, Amelia. Thanks so much for being here.

AMELIA BOURDEAU, FOUNDER AND CEO, MARKET COMPASS LLC: Great to see you. Thanks for the invite.

BARTIROMO: A lot of uncertainties from the standpoint of a -- of a market adviser like your firm is. From China to Brexit, how you invest right now and what's most important in terms of allocating capital?

BOURDEAU: What's most important right now in terms of allocating capital volatility, if volatility stays low, meaning we have certain outcomes on today especially with the Brexit vote if we get an actual outcome that they take the deal, you will see sterling rally because markets like certainty, you see equities up in the U.K., you would see the sterling rally. If we continue with some sort of uncertainty in terms of China trade and also Brexit, that's going to ride volatility, that could weigh on, you know, U.S. equities because equities don't like uncertainty and any country.

And so what we're really looking for is some certainty from the market and both the China traded negotiations and Brexit today with their vote.

BARTIROMO: Even without these two things you've got an economy that's lucky if it grows one percent in Europe for 2019.

BROOKS: That's true. Yes.

BARTIROMO: So how have you been advising your clients on that story?

BOURDEAU: To be sure, the Euro, we've always -- we've already seen a great loss in the Euro but I think it will go to parity actually with the dollar. Last week's ECB meeting, Draghi did a very interesting thing the ECB did. They introduced the new loan facility, they said the economy is slowing, they slashed their growth forecast but they said the risks are still waited to the downside which is highly unusual for the ECB after taking all those measures and the reason they said it was still waited to the downside in Europe was because of Brexit and trade negotiations. The ECB has no policy control over those --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Lindsey?

BELL: Well, the political environment over there really is also --

(CROSSTALK)

BOURDEAU: It is. Yes.

BELL: And the OECD you saw come out asking or telling the ECB, the European Commission that look, you probably need to inject more stimulus into the --

(CROSSTALK)

BOURDEAU: Yes.

BELL: -- really to stabilize things there. Is that what you expect? What do you think the next move is over there?

BOURDEAU: I do. It's very tough, we have European Parliamentary elections coming up at the end of May and some populist parties are coming to the forefront. And why that's dangerous for the Euro especially is because these populist parties are anti-Euro, and so that's also going to weigh on the European sentiment. It's also going to affect European government's ability to pass measures to stimulate the economy as well.

BROOKS: What are you telling your clients about the odds of going into recession either in Europe and/or in the United States in the next 18 months?

BOURDEAU: I think the odds are quite high that Europe will go into recession and the next -- I think even six months, I don't see the U.S. economy in recession at least for the next 12 months. Just because, growth has been so strong in jobs and wages I know we just had a disappointing jobs number for February, but I think it's a bit of an aberration.

MCDOWELL: The wages were not disappointing.

BROOKS: Yes.

BOURDEAU: No, the wages were not disappointing, yes.

MCDOWELL: The best was April 2009. And finally people are making more money.

BOURDEAU: Yes. They are and that's great. And so I don't see, you know, consumers halting their consumer spending at all. I think it will just, you know, keep on going, we'll see a little, you know, drop-off in the housing sector but, you know, the U.S. economy is strong especially relative to the rest of the world.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Amelia, great to have your insights. Thank you so much.

BOURDEAU: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Amelia Bourdeau joining us there. Coming up next. We are talking about a forewarning from the U.S. as it tells Germany to drop Huawei Technology. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo broke the news with me here first just a few weeks ago. U.S. Army Undersecretary Ryan McCarthy will join us in an exclusive interview weighing in next.

Then Musk slams this SEC. The Tesla chief suggesting regulators are infringing on his first amendment rights and holding him in contempt of court. The fallout coming up. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, March 12th. Your top stories right now 8:30 am on the East Coast. We have breaking news right now. The February consumer price index is out. It is up two-tenths of a percent right in line with the expectations. In fact, year-over-year is actually lower than the estimate. Year-over-year, the February CPI is up 1-1/2 percent versus an estimate of 2.2 percent year-over-year. So, the inflation numbers are out this morning, they are either in line, if you look month-over-month, to lower than expected if you look year-over-year on consumer price inflation. So, once again, we do have a CPI that shows very little or no inflation.

Markets this morning not really reacting, although the Dow Industrial Average has been -- has been lower all morning, because of Boeing. Boeing's stock is down again. The S&P 500 and the NASDAQ are higher this morning. The S&P just turned higher again after the CPI number, which shows no inflation. The NASDAQ up 13 points, it's adding on to big rally yesterday, up 150 points on the day yesterday on the NASDAQ.

In Europe this morning, European indices are also mixed, take a look at the FT-100 which is higher by eight points, off of the highs of the morning through. The CAC Quarante in Paris is down though, 12 points, and the DAX Index in Germany is down 24. In Asia overnight, gains across the board. Best performer was Japan. Nikkei Average up 1-3/4 percent. Hang Seng in Hong Kong up 1-1/2 percent.

Breaking news from American Airlines this morning. It says it has confidence in the safe operation of its aircraft, including the Boeing 737 Max 8 jet after reviewing extensive flight data. So here we are with American Airlines taking a cue from the FAA, which has deemed this plane safe. Many countries trying, China including -- included, have ground the 737 after the crash in Ethiopia.

Big tech today, Senator Elizabeth Warren, and the hopeful, 2020 hopeful Liz Warren, lays out her vision for regulation. The fallout from one of technology's biggest conferences, she wants to break these companies up. We're going to get into it. And then there's this, Tesla CEO Elon Musk firing back at regulators. What he said about his tweeting habits later this hour as he continues to push back on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Meanwhile, our top story this morning is the 2020 budget proposal from the President. The White House revealed a $4.7 trillion budget, highlights include $8.6 billion for a border wall, $750 billion for National Defense, with $718 billion going to the Pentagon, giving the military a $33 billion increase. The President's budget also cuts $818 billion from projected Medicare spending over 10 years. And joining me right now to talk about all of this is the Undersecretary of the United States Army, Ryan McCarthy. Secretary, it's great to have you on this program.

RYAN MCCARTHY, UNDERSECRETARY OF THE UNITED STATES ARMY: Maria, thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: It is an honor to have you. Thank you for your great service in our wonderful U.S. army.

MCCARTHY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Let's talk about the budget, here we have $22 trillion debt that we're all talking about and calls to pull it back, and yet the President proposes adding more to the defense side of the budget. You're here on the front lines. You're going to talk to us about where the priorities are.

MCCARTHY: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Can you do that?

MCCARTHY: Absolutely. Maria, the world is a very complex and dangerous place. The U.S. Army has been in sustained combat operations for 17 years. And all the while, other nations and around the world have studied our operating capabilities, our weapon systems, and have made the vast investments, both economically and militarily, to counter these capabilities. So, the reflection of the overall DoD Topline, as well as the U.S. army budget, it is aggressive, it is substantial, we're very grateful for the FY '18-'19 deal that we got, but we have to keep going to rebalance the institution and to be able to pursue national objectives worldwide.

BARTIROMO: Now one priorities is rebuilding readiness, right? Tell me about that, as well as strengthening alliances and partnerships and improving perform and affordability through reform. How are you doing that? Tell us where you see this money being allocated.

MCCARTHY: So readiness is a term that we use pretty liberally. Readiness is just like a professional athlete getting thousands of repetitions the summer before, an NFL season, or a NBA season taking free throw shots. So, our soldiers have to be ready. That mean -- when you have over 60 percent of the requirements worldwide to support national objectives militarily, it's filled by the U.S. Army. So, readies will always be our number one priority, and over half of our budget is personnel and operating and maintenance. So, we have to do what we must to have our people as ready as they can be.

The rest of the investments are in modernization. Our modernization budget, it's been -- is going to be very aggressive, but we have signaled that with FY '18 and '19 by realigning billions of dollars of our SNC portfolio, about 80 percent against six signature priorities, Long Range Precision Fires, next generation combat vehicles, futuristic helicopters, our networks, our integrated air missile defenses and soldier lethality, ballistic helmets, machine guns, things like that. So, these substantial moves were necessary because most of our systems are old. Over 40 years old in most cases for our signature weapon systems and our formations, so we have to make these choices to move forward.

BARTIROMO: And the modernization that you are in the middle of (INAUDIBLE) has a command, new command, army futures command, tell me about that. How does that help the modernization?

MCCARTHY: So along with the moves of investments, we had to look at our ourselves and how we do business and they -- what the army recognize was that it was disparate. The people involved with the decisions, what are the requirement, what is it, the how fast is the weapon system, are the range or the capabilities necessary, that's the customer or the war fighters. Then we have experimentation, we have acquisition, they were spread across this million-person organization, so what we need to do is bring it all under one roof.

So, we went through restructuring, one of the most complex that we've done since 1973 and developed a four-star command that became the bridge to academia and business to get us back to the entrepreneurial spirit of the country where we've developed some of the finest systems that our war fighters have ever used in the history of the Department of Defense.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCCARTHY: And we -- and we headquartered in Austin, Texas, it's a four-star headquarters, they operate in civilian clothes, they have a footprint and accelerator hub on the campuses of University of Texas in Austin, and a four-star commanders' building is in the University of Texas System.

BARTIROMO: And while you've done that to try to centralize things, you've also been making real cuts in the army, right? Up against --

MCCARTHY: Right.

BARTIROMO: -- lots of --

MCCARTHY: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: -- priorities to spend less money.

MCCARTHY: So we wanted to show two things in this budget, was really fiscal discipline so look at -- every program was a zero-based budget approach. The Army Leadership Secretary Esper, General Milley, our Chief of Staff, Vice Chief General McConville, our major commanders, all our four-star generals and select what we call staff codes. So, it was a principles only exercise. And of course the army staff has a sense of humor, they called it night court.

And so we sat there for about 70 plus hours, principals only, everybody had to do their own homework and then propose their budgets, and over time, we would look at how it laid in against the priorities, and if you couldn't defend it in that room, slap the table, and we either take the money or finance those efforts. It was very, very aggressive, long, hot summer but we made some very complex choices, realigning over $31 billion across the five-year futures defense plan. So, in the Department of Defense, we're really big. We do it over a five-year horizon, so the moves that are made because you have to develop most of the weapon systems and scale it to an institution of over a million people.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. All of this while some of the threats out there are trying hard to keep up or even beat the U.S. military. I understand that China, for example, has more navy ships than an U.S. has navy ships, major concern for the U.S. government has been Huawei, and the telecom Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was here a few weeks ago. Listen to what he had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Europe is pushing back on this idea that President Trump and your administration wants to ban or potentially stop, slow down the use of Huawei technology. Is that what -- is that what you found in Europe?

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: We've been out around the world just making sure everybody had the same information, that countries understand the risk of putting this Huawei technology into their I.T. systems. We can't forget these systems were designed by -- with the express work alongside, Chinese PLA, their military in China. They are creating a real risk for these countries and their systems, the security of their people. If a country adopts this and puts it in some of their critical information systems, we won't be able to share information with them.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: we talk a lot about the economic warfare going on between the U.S. and China, but there's real military aggressions as well. Is this a concern for the army?

MCCARTHY: It is. We have looked at a couple things from an investment standpoint, as well as our operating concept. The army had four -- over 40 years at -- operating business model what we called AirLand battle, and we're in the process of developing what we call multi-demand operations, is you would still have those AirLand components to (INAUDIBLE) of combat that we would fight together as a joint force, but adding cyberspace in space. So this is going to change the way we do business coupled with the army network as our investment priority, laying in over $20 billion across the five-year future defense plan. So, substantial investment and coupled with a new enterprise data strategy and how we'll protect our information.

BARTIROMO: So tell me about that because technology is really critical here, and a lot of countries are using A.I. and many people say that they're ahead of the U.S. in terms of A.I. Are we using A.I. within the military? What -- how would you characterize technology in the U.S. army?

MCCARTHY: So we developed an Artificial Intelligence Task Force retiring -- we're tying in with some world-class academic outlets, as well as companies. But a lot of the challenge with A.I. is as much cultural conditioning of how we will use that in our operating model as well as the technologies that will invest against. A.I. will be quite frankly the technology that will change warfare in the future and whoever gets their first will dominate.

BARTIROMO: And do you feel like you have the tools needed to become number one?

MCCARTHY: We're put -- we're putting our best and brightest forward, we're investing substantially, and it will be a priority for us in the future.

BARTIROMO: All right. Before you go, real quick in terms of the priorities for the U.S. army today.

MCCARTHY: Readiness, it'll always be number one. We have 180,000 troops deployed in over 140 countries on our 17th year sustained combat operations in the Middle East, so we will always be focused there, to put our men and women the best position they can when they deployed, but substantial moves in modernization and more coming here in the near future.

BARTIROMO: Secretary, it's great to have you on the program. Thanks so much.

MCCARTHY: Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Undersecretary Ryan McCarthy joining us, U.S. army. Thank you so much sir.

MCCARTHY: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Quick break and then an alarming new poll says millennials embracing are socialism as freshman politicians like Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez bring it to the forefront. Stuart Varney weighs in on that. And then mounting privacy problems, we are taking you live to the South by Southwest Conference, taking a look at how big tech is tackling major privacy concerns, all ahead, but first, a special update from the Tennis Channel.

JESSICA VILCHIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, guys, welcome back to another Tennis Channel court report for FOX Business, I'm Jessica Vilchis. The WTA's newest star, Naomi Osaka, was under the spotlight at the BNP Paribas Open today as she American, Danielle Collins. After a tight first set of 6-4, Osaka ran away with things, 6-2 in the second set to seal the match and book her spot in the round of 16. Up next for Osaka will be Belinda Bencic who won recently won a title in Dubai.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NAOMI OSAKA, TENNIS PLAYER: Yes, I mean I just kind of realized that there's nothing else I'd rather do, and I'm really privileged to be here in the first place, so I might as well, you know, enjoy every step of the way.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VILCHIS: A huge upset happened in the men's draw, as number three seed Alexander Zverev loss to the unseeded Jan-Lennard Struff. It was only the second time in his career Struff had beaten a player in the top five. And don't forget, you can watch all the action from The Fifth Major on Tennis Channel, our live daily coverage hits the air at 1:00 p.m. Eastern.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A new Harris Poll shows that young Americans are embracing socialist policies more than past generations. Joining us now the host of "VARNEY & CO." Stuart Varney to weigh in. Incredible, huh, Stu?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I think it's a problem for Republicans --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

VARNEY: -- actually these views, social -- the millennials and the Generation Z people, 38 and under, that's the group we're talking about, this is the largest voting bloc in the 2020 elections, millennials and Generation Z. This bloc firmly approves of socialistic policies. In this Harris Poll, 73 percent approved of the government providing universal government-provided healthcare. That essentially is socialized medicine. 67 percent approved of tuition-free college, that's another policy essentially out of the socialist playbook. So, we have got this large voting bloc heavily in favor of socialist style policies and the Republicans are nowhere to be found on these issues.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

VARNEY: I mean I think it's a problem for them.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: And the President has, you know, Breitbart interview, he understands this. He says, "Look, it's easy to campaign on socialism, you offer free stuff, and you probably get, you know, you're going to win, not necessarily going to win, but you're going to do well. Then he says 10 years later, "Your country's destroyed," but that message is not getting through to millennials. They support socialistic policies, problem for Republicans in my opinion.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Wait until the 16-year-olds start voting.

VARNEY: Oh, stop it, Maria. Don't want to ruin my day even though it's only Tuesday.

BARTIROMO: I'm sorry.

BROOKS: I think we should the voting age to 40. What do you think --

VARNEY: What was that?

BROOKS: Stuart, Stuart, this is Arthur. How are you doing?

VARNEY: How are -- is that Arthur Brooks?

BROOKS: Yes, yes, yes.

VARNEY: The man (INAUDIBLE) you want to move the voting age to 40?

BROOKS: Yes, I figure --

VARNEY: I'm OK. I'm 70. I'll vote.

BROOKS: You're 70?

VARNEY: Yes.

BROOKS: Oh, I want to look like Stuart when I'm 70. You know --

VARNEY: Oh, I love you, Arthur. Love you.

BROOKS: Stu, you know, you and I have talked about this for years and, you know, you and I agree on everything as you know. I'm less worried about young people saying they're socialists today, and maybe I'm just a Pollyanna.

VARNEY: Good.

BROOKS: But, you know, what young people call themselves has very much to do with their sense of dignity and aspiration and opportunity and optimism.

VARNEY: Yes.

BROOKS: And it seems -- I mean I've seen it.

VARNEY: Yes.

BROOKS: You know, in 1976, two-thirds of young people 18 to 30 voted for Jimmy Carter by 1984, two-thirds voter for Ronald Reagan, they're very -- young people are --

VARNEY: It's fascinating.

BROOKS: -- very, you know, promiscuous in their -- sorry. In their voting patterns and --

VARNEY: But will you --

BROOKS: And the way they see themselves.

VARNEY: Will you please come on my show tomorrow?

BARTIROMO: Oh, come on, Stuart.

VARNEY: And, you know --

BARTIROMO: You're going to use that for --

VARNEY: -- I'm going to steal him.

BARTIROMO: You're going to use this time for that?

VARNEY: I'm going to steal him off you.

BARTIROMO: Come on, Stu.

VARNEY: I am. I'm stealing him.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll see you in about 10 minutes, Stuart. Top of the show, "VARNEY & CO." begins right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join -- we will see you then, Stuart. Thank You. Coming up, Musk versus the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Tesla CEO taking on regulators over his tweeting. The details coming up. And then global privacy concerns, we are take a live look at how big tech is battling mounting privacy issues. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Shares of DICK'S Sporting Goods tumbling this morning despite a double beat on earnings and revenue.

Gerri Willis on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange with more. Hey, Gerri.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, Dagen. That's right. So DICK'S coming in beating on both the top and the bottom line, coming in at $1.22 on earnings versus $1.06, 2.49 billion in revenues versus 2.48 billion, even those that -- those shares slumping this morning and why? It's same-store sales. They came in 3.7 percent below, lower versus expecting of down 3.3 percent. Now the company is optimistic in its conversation, its projections for next year. If you remember, it's been a year since this company banned the sales of assault style rifles and limited -- halted sales of firearms to customers under 21. Customers have been taking it out on DICK'S and trimming their visits to the store.

Meanwhile, Tesla, Elon Musk must sing in the court filings. He did not file a terms of a fraud settlement that restricted his social media use, this to a federal judge who could hold him in contempt of court. The SEC has required preapprovals of Elon Musk's tweets, but apparently, there is one tweet that got through directly from Mr. Musk which said that they would make 500,000 cars in 2019. So, it was a production estimate that the SEC has trouble with. We know that -- we know that Elon's problems with the SEC go way back. He's called them a short-seller exchange commission, and the SEC obviously entrenched here on this idea that he is violating terms of his settlement. The original tweet that offended he said he had secured funding to take the company private. Dagen, back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Gerri Willis at the New York Stock Exchange. Still ahead, mounting privacy problems. We're taking you live to South by Southwest, that conference for a look at how big tech is tackling privacy concerns. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Big tech companies facing backlash at South by Southwest. Hillary Vaughn in Austin with the details. Hey, Hillary.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, Dagen. Well, Instagram Cofounder, Mike Krieger, responding to Senator Elizabeth Warren's plan to cut Facebook down to size by having regulators retroactively reject Facebook's acquisition of Instagram.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE KRIEGER, COFOUNDER, INSTAGRAM: I'm imagining the sci-fi version of this which is like the time traveler had to go back and unwind the Instagram acquisition, you prevent it from happening to like make sure it happens (INAUDIBLE)

KRIEGER: You know, the cliche that every company is a tech company is increasingly true. So, like, breaking up tech or, like, having those kinds of conversations, I just -- I think the conversation will go better and lead to better policy if we're really specific on the problems that we're trying to solve, and then specific on, like, what the implementation would be.

VAUGHN: Warren is also targeting Google and Amazon, saying that they too need to be cut down to size because she thinks they'll be held accountable more easily that way. Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Hillary. Hillary Vaughn in Austin. Lindsey, thank you. Arthur, so good to see you.

BROOKS: Nice to see you.

MCDOWELL: Book again. Love Your Enemies.

BROOKS: Love Your Enemies. It's on sale today.

MCDOWELL: We need to do a podcast just based on our conversations in the commercial break sometime without having to --

BROOKS: I would love that. I would love that.

MCDOWELL: I'll make it happen right now. "VARNEY & CO." Stuart, it is all yours.

VARNEY: Good morning, Dagen.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thank you so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, March 12. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast on the button. Markets this morning are lower. We are near -- well, we're off of the lows of the morning but certainly off of the highs as well.

Dow industrials down 65 points, Boeing is now another drag on the Dow this morning. S&P 500 just went negative a few minutes ago, down a quarter point but the NASDAQ up, this morning up 8-1/2, up nine points right now on NASDAQ, on top of big gains yesterday. Stocks staged a late-day rally yesterday driven by technology stocks. DowIndustrials were up 200 points, three- quarters of a percent, the S&P was up 1-1/2 percent.

But take a look at the NASDAQ, it was up 150 points due to the strength in tech, better than two percent on the session yesterday. Global markets this morning are mixed. Take a look at the European indices where the FT-100 is up 18 points, quarter of a percent but the CAC Quarante in Paris is down 15 and the DAX Index in Germany down 25. In Asia overnight, gains across-the-board the best performer was Japan, Nikkei Average up 1-3/4 percent.

Well, the groundings of Boeing 737 Max 8 jet are expanding across the world. Nearly half of all of the jets that have been delivered since May of '17 are now parked. The fallout coming up this morning for Boeing as the stock trades down another two percent as we speak. Carlos Ghosn replaced the Renault-Nissan alliance unveiling a new board structure as the automakers chart their path forward. As you know, Carlos Ghosn is now out of jail on bail.

Tesla CEO Elon Musk fires back at regulators this morning. What he said about his tweeting habits later this hour. Stock is down again 1-1/2 percent. And the internet us turning 30 years old. Google celebrates with its doodle today but the man behind the World Wide Web has a warning about the future.

court ruling ended safe harbour #124system over govt snooping concerns

Reuters

BRUSSELS

The EU's highest court decision to strike down a deal that allows thousands of companies to easily transfer personal data from Europe to the United States, in a landmark ruling on Tuesday follows revelations of mass US government snooping.

Many companies, both US and European use the Safe Harbour system to help them get round cumbersome checks to transfer data between offices on both sides of the Atlantic.

That includes payroll and human resources information as well as lucrative data used for online advertising, which is of particular importance to tech companies.

But the decision by the Court of Justice of the European Union (ECJ) sounds the death knell for the system, set up by the European Commission 15 years ago. It is used by over 4,000 firms including IBM, Google and Ericsson.

The court said Safe Harbour did not sufficiently protect EU citizens' personal data since the requirements of American national security, public interest and law enforcement trumped the privacy safeguards contained in the framework.

In addition, EU citizens have no means of legal recourse against the misuse of their data in the United States, the court said. A bill is currently winding its way through the US Congress to give Europeans the right to legal redress.

The ECJ in its ruling referred to revelations from former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden, which included that the Prism programme allowed US authorities to harvest private information directly from big tech companies such as Apple, Facebook and Google.

IBM said the ruling created commercial uncertainty and jeopardised the flow of data across borders.

"The free movement of data across borders is the foundation of the global economy, facilitating everything from financial services and manufacturing to shipping and retail," said Christopher Padilla, vice president of Government and Regulatory Affairs at IBM.

Any company with a centralised HR database in the United States would need to transfer personal data there, and companies that do not have data centres in Europe often ship the data from their European clients across the Atlantic, lawyers said.

However, they also said most multinationals, such as Facebook and Microsoft, would probably be able to continue with business as usual as they already had alternative legal channels for transferring data to the United States.

The ECJ ruling became effective immediately and the European Commission said it would continue to work with the United States on a revamped data transfer deal to fill the void.

"In the light of the ruling, we will continue this work towards a new and safe framework for the transfer of personal data across the Atlantic," Commission Vice President Frans Timmermans told a news conference.

US loses adequate protection status

Without Safe Harbour, the United States loses its status in the EU as a country that provides "adequate protection" for personal data.

The EU has granted that status to only 11 countries worldwide. For transfers to any other country, such as Japan, companies have to draw up contracts establishing privacy protections between groups or seek approval from data protection authorities, something they will now be required to do for transfers to the United States.

"The EU's highest court has pulled the rug under the feet of thousands of companies that have been relying on Safe Harbour, "said Monika Kuschewsky, special counsel at law firm Covington." All these companies are now forced to find an alternative mechanism for their data transfers to the US"

The group of EU data protection authorities, known as the Article 29 Working Party, said it would hold discussions this week to "determine the consequences on transfers" of data and schedule an extraordinary meeting shortly.

The court case stemmed from a complaint by Austrian law student Max Schrems, who challenged Facebook's transfers of European users' data to its American servers because of the risk of US snooping, in light of Snowden's revelations in 2013.

The European Commission separately demanded a review of Safe Harbour to ensure that US authorities' access to Europeans' data would be proportionate and limited to what is absolutely necessary.

Schrems filed his complaint to the Irish Data Protection Commissioner, as Facebook's European headquarters is in Ireland.

The case eventually wound its way up to the Luxembourg-based ECJ, which was asked to rule on whether national data privacy watchdogs could unilaterally suspend the Safe Harbour framework if they had concerns about US privacy safeguards.

"The judgement makes it clear that US businesses cannot simply aid US espionage efforts in violation of European fundamental rights," said 28-year-old Schrems.

urn:contentItem:5WKN-WTV1-DY6J-M012-00000-00Utah among states stating its concerns with big tech2019-07-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:46ZLexisNexisUtah among states stating its concerns with big techArt Raymond Deseret News

By Art Raymond

Deseret News

SALT LAKE CITY - Representatives of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google roundly denied their respective companies are stifling competition and innovation through sheer size, market dominance or conduct at a U.S. House hearing.

Those assertions, however, were scoffed at by some industry experts who also appeared before the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Antitrust, Commercial and Administrative Law. Big tech is under fire and facing increasing scrutiny as state attorneys general - including Utah's Sean Reyes - line up behind federal agencies for potential actions while a new investigation opens in the European Union.

The three lawyers and one economist from the big four U.S. tech interests all claimed Tuesday that their employers are in industries where they face "fierce" competition and are forced to constantly innovate to stay viable.

But Columbia University legal scholar Tim Wu characterized that testimony as something that could have "come from a hearing in 2005 or a fantasy zone" and said big tech's control over markets is having an undeniable chilling effect on new innovation.

"I think we face a vitally important question here," Wu said. "Whether the United States will remain the place that new industries start ... where inventors think they have a chance to challenge the dominant firms of their day, where innovation flourishes.

"I think that is something that has come into question. I think that we face, across the economy, an overconsolidation and overconcentration of many industries, and I think this is particularly evident, and in fact extreme, in the tech industries."

All four of the companies invited to testify before the panel have remarkable success arcs, though each began humbly in dorm rooms or garages, and have amassed enormous economic clout. As of the end of June, Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google occupied four of the top five slots for U.S. businesses when ranked by market capitalization, and two of them, Amazon and Apple, have spent brief moments north of the $1 trillion mark in the last year.

Representatives of the companies touted their contributions to the U.S. economy in their testimony, with Adam Cohen, Google's director of economic policy, detailing some of his company's investments and noting tech companies collectively employ some 12 million, accounting for 8% of the total U.S. workforce.

"Google's products and services create signficant value, generating an estimated $335 billion in economic activity in 2018," Cohen said. "Last year we hired more than 10,000 people and invested over $9 billion in data centers and offices across the country."

Subcommittee Chairman Rep. David Cicilline, D-R.I., acknowledged the contributions made by the four companies called to testify but noted some of the mechanisms that helped pave the way for the growth of the digital economy, and big tech concerns, were now failing to address market issues.

"In an effort to promote and continue this new economy, Congress and antitrust enforcers allowed these firms to regulate themselves with little oversight," Cicilline said. "As a result, the internet has become increasingly concentrated, less open and grown hostile to innovation and entrepreneurship."

Reyes shares concerns about the impacts of big tech on the competitive landscape, as well as how dominant digital platforms are accruing and commodifying troves of personal data gathered on individuals who use their products.

Reyes and over 40 other state attorneys general co-signed a letter last month outlining issues they share with how big tech firms operate, following a conference on antitrust issues in Omaha, Nebraska. The 27-page document went to the Federal Trade Commission, which along with the U.S. Department of Justice, is tasked with antitrust oversight in the U.S.

It notes that companies like Google and Facebook, that give away their products, have created new challenges for enforcement and regulation under current statute.

"Recent antitrust enforcement in technology markets has often failed to meaningfully evaluate non-price aspects of competition such as innovation, consumer choice and privacy," the letter reads. "Recent comments by Makan Delrahim, antitrust chief at the United States Department of Justice, reaffirm the commitment of government antitrust enforcers to utilize current antitrust doctrine to address consumer harm in zero-price markets."

The letter also notes that mega-platforms can leverage power acquired via so-called "network effects," wherein the more users who engage the product/platform the more useful, and valuable and influential it becomes. One of the potential outgrowths of that power of scale is being able to identify which new companies may represent competitive threats before they get big enough to actually compete.

"Because network effects tend to produce a winner-take-all market, winners tend to monitor the landscape for startups with the potential to unseat them," the letter reads. "Competition concerns arise when dominant platforms can leverage their unique access to data to identify these nascent competitors and acquire or exclude them."

When asked about the current status of any actions aimed at big tech companies and possible anti-competitive conduct, Reyes said he could not "confirm or deny the existence of any specific investigations at this time," but did say that it's typical for investigations to stay under wraps in complex cases.

"As conversations about these issues develop, Utah will continue to actively participate," Reyes said in a prepared response. "It is also worth noting that antitrust investigations into complex industries frequently take a year or longer before they become public or result in a lawsuit being filed."

Reyes noted that Utah, which has an explicit free market clause within its state constitution, has a more robust statutory mandate to enforce on antitrust issues than some other states.

"The existence of a constitutional provision makes antitrust enforcement a clearer priority in Utah than it may be in some states, particularly the few that lack specific antitrust laws," Reyes said. "Utah has a history of vigorous antitrust enforcement that benefits both consumers and innovative small businesses."

Some industry watchers say congressional action to revamp both the regulatory realm and standing antitrust laws is necessary to take any meaningful action against perceived antitrust activity in the tech realm.

But Wu and others, including University of Utah S.J. Quinney School of Law professor Jorge Contreras, believe there is sufficient basis in a 130-year-old piece of federal legislation.

"The 1890 Sherman Antitrust Act is fine," Contreras said. "It conceivably covers any of this conduct. Where we've drifted away is with the court's interpretation of the Sherman Act."

That drift, which many attribute to legal scholar and former U.S. Solicitor General Robert Bork, was fomented by the idea that antitrust enforcement should be focused on consumer harm rather than competitive issues.

Contreras said even acknowledging the Bork-influenced shift toward a consumer-centric interpretation of antitrust statute, he and other legal experts where taken aback by the lack of a federal response to Facebook's $1 billion acquisition of image sharing app Instagram in 2012. The move was seen by many as a case of Facebook simply buying up a potential competitor before it grew big enough to pose a business risk.

"I think the Facebook-Instagram merger, with almost no opposition from the government, really sent off alarm bells, at least among academics and observers," Contreras said. "The collective response was, 'What is going on here? We expected at least a good fight about this.'"

While U.S. law enforcement and regulatory agencies ponder which fights they're willing to wage, European regulators are stepping into the ring.

On Wednesday, the European Union announced it is investigating whether Amazon uses data from independent retailers to gain an unfair advantage, a decision that could lead to changes in how the internet's biggest marketplace works.

The move echoes similar antitrust actions against Google and Microsoft that have led to billions in fines.

The EU's antitrust chief, Margrethe Vestager, said she's taking a "very close look at Amazon's business practices and its dual role as marketplace and retailer."

In addition to selling its own products, Amazon allows third-party retailers to sell their goods through its site. Last year, more than half of the items sold on Amazon worldwide were from third-party sellers.

In doing so, Amazon collects data about activity on its platform that, the EU says, it might be able to use to favor its own products for sale. In particular, the EU will look at how Amazon determines which trader is selected as the default seller of an item that a customer wants to buy.

urn:contentItem:5X15-0YJ1-JCB3-X291-00000-00Utah Attorney General Sean Reyes joins multistate antitrust probe into Google’s business practices2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:46ZLexisNexisUtah Attorney General Sean Reyes joins multistate antitrust probe into Google’s business practicesThomas Burr

Washington • Utah Attorney General Sean Reyes joined 49 of his colleagues across the country to launch an investigation of Google for possible antitrust violations in its dominance of the online world that could be snuffing out smaller competitors and cornering the market on advertising dollars.

“There’s no question that Google is the dominant player when it comes to internet searches with nearly 90 percent of the [market’s] share,” Reyes, a Republican, said Monday in front of the U.S. Supreme Court. “And there’s nothing wrong with being the dominant player if it’s done fairly. That’s what our investigation intends to uncover and reveal — whether Google is playing by the rules and acting fairly.”

The massive bipartisan investigation, which includes 48 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico, will look at Google’s business practices to see if it violates state or federal antitrust laws, specifically looking at whether its dominance of online advertising and searches harms consumers.

“There's a fine line sometimes between aggressive business practices and illegal ones.” Reyes said Monday. “Usually the line is very clear. And again our investigation will determine whether Google has crossed that line.”

The multistate probe could also touch on how Google ranks searches and how it protects users' personal information.

The investigation — a fairly unprecedented move that brings together, in some cases, ideologically opposed forces — comes as big tech companies face increased scrutiny from states and the federal government over their control of the internet and the potential to block upstarts and innovation.

“Many consumers believe that the internet is free. Certainly we know from Google’s profits of $117 billion that it is not free,” said Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, a Republican who is leading the investigation with D.C. Attorney General Karl Racine, a Democrat. “And this is a company that dominates all aspects of advertising on the internet and searching on the internet, as they dominate the buyer side, the seller side, the auction side and even the video side with YouTube. This investigation is not a lawsuit. It is an investigation to determine the facts.”

Google did not respond to a request for comment.

In a blog post, Kent Walker, Google’s senior vice president for global affairs, said last week that the company’s services support thousands of jobs and help small businesses.

“At the same time, it’s of course right that governments should have oversight to ensure that all successful companies, including ours, are complying with the law,” Walker wrote, adding that Google has answered many of the questions raised over many years in the United States and abroad. “We have always worked constructively with regulators and we will continue to do so. We look forward to showing how we are investing in innovation, providing services that people want, and engaging in robust and fair competition.”

Monday's announcement is not the first foray into probing the massive provider of internet products, though it might mark one of the largest investigations into its operations.

Utah’s Reyes and Racine, the D.C. attorney general, sent a letter to Google more than two years ago seeking to understand how it ranks links related to its own businesses.

“There used to be a day when we search Google that we would be presented with links unrelated to the Google businesses,” Racine said Monday. “There's a very compelling analysis to suggest that the overwhelming number of query responses relate to Google businesses and or advertisers that pay for that slot within those links.”

The European Commission has also brought three antitrust actions against Google.

The tech giant is also under investigation by the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission, the former of which recently made its first legal demand for Google records, The Washington Post reported.

Only California, which is home to Google’s headquarters, and Alabama did not join their fellow state attorneys general in the probe.

urn:contentItem:60C3-5091-JBCN-451D-00000-00Utah Rep. John Curtis introduces Informing Consumers about Smart Devices Act2020-07-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:46ZLexisNexisGOVT AND POLITICSUtah Rep. John Curtis introduces Informing Consumers about Smart Devices ActConnor Richards

United States Rep. John Curtis, R-Utah, introduced a consumer data privacy protection bill Monday that would require manufacturers to disclose whether smart appliances and devices are equipped with audio or visual capabilities.

The Informing Consumers about Smart Devices Act, which Curtis introduced alongside Rep. Seth Moulton, D-Massachusetts, and Rep. Gus Bilirakis, R-Florida, states that "each manufacturer of a covered device shall disclose whether the covered device manufactured by the manufacturer contains a camera or microphone as a component of the covered device" and that failing to do so "shall be treated as a violation of a rule defining an unfair or deceptive act or practice" prescribed in the Federal Trade Commission Act.

"Any person who violates this Act or a regulation promulgated under this Act shall be subject to the penalties and entitled to the privileges and immunities provided in the Federal Trade Commission Act," the text of the bill states.

The bill specifically targets smart appliances like refrigerators and pet feeders and would not apply to cell phones, laptops, tablets "or any device that a consumer would reasonably expect to have a microphone or camera" or a device that is "specifically marketed as a camera, telecommunications device, or microphone."

The bipartisan bill comes a year after reports that Amazon employees listen to voice recordings captured by Echo speakers to improve the device's speech recognition, as the Associated Press reported in April 2019, leading to increased scrutiny over the ways smart devices impact personal privacy.

"We should be allowed to make informed decisions about the electronic eavesdroppers we invite into our homes," Moulton said in a press release. "But we can't do it if big tech hides microphones and cameras that are always listening in refrigerators, toasters and other household gadgets."

Moulton introduced a related bill in July 2019, the Automatic Listening Exploitation Act, that would "limit the use, record or transmission of any speech or sound captured by a smart speaker, or any video image captured by a video doorbell, and to prohibit … such use, recording or transmission without the express consent of the consumer."

Curtis said the bill "balances protecting American consumers with continuing to foster innovation" and would "allow regulatory flexibility without hamstringing the technological pioneers who are developing smart technologies, while ensuring consumers are aware of the capabilities of items they are putting in their homes."

The disclosure requirement would not apply to devices manufactured or sold before the bill passed and would require the Federal Trade Commission to work with manufactures to establish guidelines for how to disclose whether products are equipped with cameras or microphones.

urn:contentItem:5NP5-D8W1-F03R-N0W7-00000-00Utilities Head Toward Bull Market Highs2017-06-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:46ZLexisNexisUtilities Head Toward Bull Market HighsAlan Farley

Jun 01, 2017( Investopedia Stock Analysis: http://www.investopedia.com/markets/#axzz22OU7Ufra Delivered by Newstex) Utilities have emerged from their long slumber and are challenging bull market highs, despite Wall Street's unrelenting focus on growth and risk-taking. The sector's quiet strength highlights similarly constructive action in other traditionally defensive[1] market groups, including bonds and precious metals. Taken together, investors may love big tech but are hedging their bets with safe havens that should outperform if the broad averages turn lower in coming months.

Even so, choose exposure wisely due to broad regulatory, corporate and resource variations, with self-regulated companies performing better than those forced through legislative channels to increase rates. Utilities more tightly levered[2] to commodities are lagging as well, with lower natural gas and crude oil prices undermining profits. As a result, it makes sense to stick with industry leaders while limiting exposure to broad-based sector funds.NextEra Energy, Inc. (NEE[3]) topped out at $73.75 in 2007 and sold off to $33.81 in 2008. It completed a round trip into the prior high in 2012 and broke out one year later, entering a strong uptrend that's continued into 2017. However, volatility has risen sharply since 2014, with deep corrections and vigorous bounces defining two-sided action, in which bulls have withstood mounting selling pressure. The stock topped out[4] at $132 in July 2016 and sold off in multiple waves that reached a seven-month low at $110 after the November election. It turned higher into January, reaching the prior high in March and pulled a back in the last phase of a cup and handle pattern, ahead of a May breakout that continues to add points at a rapid pace. Given technically overbought[5] readings, market players should wait for a pullback to new support at $134 before getting on board. The company pays a 2.62% dividend.American Electric Power, Inc. (AEP[6]) stalled in the low-50s in 1998 following a long uptrend and reversed at that resistance level in 2001 and 2007. A 2013 test yielded a multi-decade breakout, followed by a strong uptrend that's eased into a rising channel[7] with support in the upper-50s and resistance in the mid-70s. A bounce that started at channel support in December 2016 has now reached within 4-points of channel resistance. Also, the stock has just completed a 100% retracement into resistance at the July 2016 high at $71.32, raising odds for a multi week reversal and pullback that could offer a lower-risk entry price. The 200-day EMA rising through the mid-60s looks like a natural downside target, with that level offering more favorable reward: risk than buying a breakout. The company pays a 3.20% dividend.Nisource, Inc. (NI[8]) topped out in the lower teens in 1998 and reversed at that level in 2001. It took more than a decade for the next return trip, with price reaching resistance in 2013 following a 10-point rally off the 2009 bear market low. It broke out into 2014, grinding higher in a narrow rising channel that paused in the second half of 2015. It reentered the pattern at year's end and continued to gain ground into the July 2016 high at $26.94. A decline into December dropped the stock to an 8-month low at $21.17 ahead of a recovery wave that stalled above $24 in March 2017. It broke out above that resistance level about two weeks ago and charged higher, lifting within a point of resistance this week. On Balance Volume (OBV)[9] has matched bullish price action, setting the stage for a breakout, perhaps after a final reversal yields a test at new support (blue line). The company pays a 2.61% dividend.The Bottom LineUtilities have attracted steady buying pressure in recent months, despite the media's narrow focus on growth stocks, and could post new highs in coming months. <Disclosure: the author held no positions in aforementioned stocks at the time of publication. > [ 1]: http://www.investopedia.com/terms/d/defensivestock.asp [ 2]:   http://www.investopedia.com/terms/l/leverage.asp [ 3]:   http://www.investopedia.com/markets/stocks/nee/ [ 4]:   http://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/atop.asp [ 5]:   http://www.investopedia.com/terms/o/overbought.asp [ 6]:   http://www.investopedia.com/markets/stocks/aep/ [ 7]:   http://www.investopedia.com/terms/a/ascendingchannel.asp [ 8]:   http://www.investopedia.com/markets/stocks/ni/ [ 9]:   http://www.investopedia.com/terms/o/onbalancevolume.asp
